channel.title: SPS Daily — Science, Philosophy & Society
channel.description: A curated digest of the best writing on science, philosophy, and society.

item.title: How the Bernie Goetz Shootings Explain the Trump Era
item.description: A notorious event in 1984 divided New Yorkers in ways that feel extremely familiar four decades later. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: A Friendship Spanning Bombay Prep Schools and Connecticut Strip Malls
item.description: An excerpt from Every Happiness by Reena Shah Though Ruchi needed the job, any job, her first impulse when Deepa finally called was to say no. Deepa talked as if no time had passed, like she hadn’t avoided Ruchi’s calls since the housewarming in August, like it wasn’t now January 1985. Deepa went on (via Electric Literature)

item.title: Morton Feldman’s Music of Stillness
item.description: In his centenary year, the increasingly revered composer offers an uneasy refuge from the algorithmic din. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Nancy Kerrigan Persisted
item.description: The Olympic figure skater and all-American girl has overcome a lot, besides Tonya Harding. But, at a holiday ice show on Long Island, she still sparkles. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Witnessing Another Public Killing in Minneapolis
item.description: Videos of Alex Pretti’s fatal shooting, rapidly disseminated on social media, reveal a brazen display of brute power. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: The Battle for Minneapolis
item.description: As Donald Trump brings his retribution to a liberal city, citizens, protesters, and civic leaders try to protect one another. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Believe Your Eyes
item.description: People are risking their lives to document agents in Minneapolis. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: Another Death in Minneapolis
item.description: After killing another American, federal officials again offer an explanation that appears to be directly contradicted by available evidence. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: Exclusive poll: Let Burnham stand, voters say
item.description: Over half of voters in Manchester think Labour is wrong to block him (via New Statesman)

item.title: Yes, It’s Fascism
item.description: Until recently, I thought it a term best avoided. But now, the resemblances are too many and too strong to deny. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: Tom Stoppard’s Secret—And Mine
item.description: Like the playwright, I grew up knowing nothing about my family's connection to the Holocaust. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: International Law Is Holding Democracies Back
item.description: The United States should use this moment to argue for a different approach to the rules of war. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: Andy Burnham blocked from standing in Gorton and Denton
item.description: Claims of a stitch up by Starmer’s allies on the NEC have already been circulating (via New Statesman)

item.title: Gus Kenworthy Lived an Olympic Version of “Heated Rivalry”
item.description: Ahead of a comeback in Milan, the Olympic freestyle skier and actor discusses alley-oops, auditions, and coming out of the closet as a professional athlete. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Trump’s Greenland Fiasco
item.description: The President caused a crisis in NATO and deepened European distrust toward the U.S. to end up with basically the same set of options that existed months ago. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Restaurant Review: Wild Cherry
item.description: Inside a playhouse now owned by A24, a new restaurant offers frogs’ legs, a killer cheeseburger, and a heavy dose of haute-theatrical glamour. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Emily Nussbaum on Jane Kramer’s “Founding Cadre”
item.description: Her startling 1970 article, based on months of reporting on radical feminist pioneers, was an outlier for the period—coolly observational but full of emotion. (via The New Yorker)

item.title: Proximate Atrocities
item.description: by Christopher Hall “The essence of repression lies simply in turning something away, and keeping it at a distance, from the conscious.” –Freud, “Repression” “Time and again, in conversation with friends, some of who have lost family members in this killing spree, there is a sense that one must be g (via 3 Quarks Daily)

item.title: Art Beyond Entertainment
item.description: by Chris Horner There are many great authors of the past who have survived centuries of oblivion and neglect, but it is still an open question whether they will be able to survive an entertaining version of what they have to say. —Hannah Arendt A book should be an ice axe for the frozen sea… (via 3 Quarks Daily)

item.title: The Ten Year Affair made me hate myself
item.description: Erin Somers’ adultery novel is targeted at downwardly mobile, media-adjacent millennials (via New Statesman)

item.title: Minneapolis Is a Second Amendment Wake-Up Call
item.description: The federal killing of a Minnesota ICU nurse should worry every American. (via The Atlantic)

item.title: Let's nitpick about the physics of Stranger Things, not its ending
item.description: Feedback has seen all the fuss about the finale of Stranger Things, but would like to point out that if we're going to dissect the plot, we have bigger things to worry about (via New Scientist)

item.title: How to spot the lunar X and V
item.description: Time it right each month, and you can spot two fleeting tricks of light on the lunar surface. Abigail Beall is planning ahead (via New Scientist)
